newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil sees '96 current account gap at 3 pct/GDP.
newsitem.headline: Brazil sees '96 current account gap at 3 pct/GDP.

text.p: The Brazilian Central Bank expects the current account deficit by the end of the year to be equivalent to 3.0 percent of gross domestic product, said Altamir Lopes, the head of the bank's economic department.
Lopes told reporters he also expected foreign direct investment to total $7.5 billion by the end of 1996.
The bank announced Monday that the current account gap in the first eight months of the year was $11 billion, equivalent to 2.81 percent of GDP.
Direct foreign investment in the January to August period of 1996 totalled $5.423 billion.
Government officials have been predicting direct foreign investment of between $7.0 billion and $8.0 billion in 1996, versus $3.928 billion in the whole of 1995.
